Whenever you see "bitcoin mining is / isn't profitable", you must mentally insert the qualifier "at current difficulty", even if the writer failed to do so. Otherwise it is a meaningless statement. At variable difficulty, bitcoin mining is ALWAYS profitable for some miners.

setup instructions for #bitcoin satellite (USB dongle +software decoding): - budget approach use SDR + software - faster CPU needed - mostly for low bandwidths stream current blocks/transactions - can receive high speed also in theory - single stream https://github.com/Blockstream/satellite/blob/master/doc/sdr.md

the ring of 3 uplinks with pair-wise cross visible satellites should allow us to keep global #bitcoin broadcast running even with and two of three uplinks terrestrial internet outages or disconnections

setup for #bitcoin satellite basic kit (TBS 5927 usb DVB-S2): - lower cost still HW accelerated USB connected - low CPU cost on computer - receive low speed current block & high speed history streams simultaneously (with 60cm/24in+ dish) - single dish https://github.com/Blockstream/satellite/blob/master/doc/tbs.md

setup instructions for #bitcoin satellite pro kit (novra s400 dual DVB-S2 ethernet): - standalone no need for USB connected computer - multicasts UDP/IP bitcoin data over LAN for fullnodes - dual satellite decoder for areas with overlap so 2x data rate https://github.com/Blockstream/satellite/blob/master/doc/s400.md
looks like someone has the pro-kit with UDP/IP decoded data? what do you have to do to get bitcoin core to receive those?

due to the new lossless #bitcoin transaction compression from Arvid Norberg and @pwuille it's actually reduced to 232GB. (but then there is FEC overhead etc). also if you get the pro equipment and can reach two satellites it comes down to about 10days (independent FEC streams)

"The network allows users to connect a #Bitcoin full node and download the entirety of the Bitcoin blockchain, from the original genesis block in 2009 until today, without needing to connect to the internet. "
"Because if you’re not streaming your Bitcoin from space, you’re not really cool, are you?"

Different properties, starlink: - per user subscription cost - metered data per user (not broadcast) - tied to subscriber info vs anonymous @Blockstream #bitcoin satellite is: - anonymous - broadcast - no signup - free

definitely better. I started with a 2400 baud. then 14.4kbaud then 33.6kbaud and then 56kbaud. curiously the iridum go is 2400baud :) it's enough to send bitcoin transactions in a couple of seconds tho.
the FEC improvements and overhead reductions are from Greg Maxwell (who did codec work on vorbis before #Bitcoin) and @blockstream signal processing specialist @igor_auad
#bitcoin only. there is an up-rated lightning data API now though able to send up to 1MB messages up from previous 10kB messages.

"with new Asia/Pacific @blockstream #bitcoin satellite coverage you could sync a full-node and keep it in sync while on a boat in transit from Alaska to China" -Chris Cook (@blockstream mining & satellite head)
sounds like you're good to go then. sending Bitcoin transactions doesn't cost much even at $10/MB on 2400 baud iridum edge as transactions are so small 250bytes +/-.

#bitcoin lightning paid satellite message API https://blockstream.com/satellite-api/ per message limit increased from 10kB to 1MB, so I guess you can now dunk via 1MB video message instead of 10kB text message.

people kept asking for kits, so we made them. and now with full-sync, new hardware accelerated DVB-S2 protocol, and option with the pro version for ethernet UDP/IP multicast of #Bitcoin transactions & blocks for your home or office LAN, and dual satellite feeds for faster sync

Bitcoin vs layer2: Liquid vs Lightning is not a one dimensional comparison. Security: Bitcoin > Liquid > Lightning > Exchange Trust/uncensorable/unseizable: Bitcoin > Lightning > Liquid > Exchange Confidentiality: Liquid > Lightning > Bitcoin Speed: Lightning > Liquid > Bitcoin

One can label things, even for Bitcoin. But if it doesn't aid understanding properties it doesn't help. LQ is what it is, and I think tech audience gets it. It's interesting to think about p2p network properties distinct from individual node capability. Sum is more than the parts

Try this: hacker hijacks enough firewalls, BGP routes etc to selectively filter Bitcoin blocks to > 50% miners. Now hacker can reorg. If you have coins previously held by hacker, does the (hacker in the) network have custody of bitcoin about to be rolled back out of your wallet?

"federation controls the peg Bitcoin" sort of, but gray, technically if the multisig keys are in tamper reset HSMs. "They can spend the Bitcoin" maybe. If they collude to steal, and succeed to tamper with enough things without wiping the HSMs.

Who has custody of Bitcoin? Bitcoin is p2p and processed by miners. But miners are not custodians right. Liquid is a kind of peer to peer network of blocksigners which individually don't control anything much unilaterally, even via hardware tamper prone to wipe itself by trying.

Right it's like a p2p network of HSM block-signers which includes the HSM peg operation Where it takes a big threshold of them to successfully and simultaneously hack. Federated HSM peg seems fair. Not custody, not fullnode auditable trustless like Bitcoin either, but in between

Liquid is higher security, designed for large amounts vs lightning. Tradeoff is not as trustless. Trust of unseizability and security are slightly different. But if your LN Bitcoin were stolen from hot wallet via hack or hostile close/DoS, how much difference is that to the user.

some bigger leap incremental things like confidential transactions, and simplicity (formal proof focussed low level next gen bitcoin script upgrade). they don't change the architecture, just properties (privacy and extensibility respectively) within the #bitcoin architecture.

so basically everything within #bitcoin protocol - with only respect for the many world class system engineers and protocol experts who work on it - has been in the domain of micro-optimization, incremental improvement and sub-protocol optimization. and in a security first way

this unusual design space situation, that a robust design works and all-close variants are worse, minor improvements degrade other factors more, have unusable complexity, or just don't work is why people will say to "new better than bitcoin" - default assumption highly unlikely.

In 2013 I spent quite some time, over months looking re-examing crypto architecture, armed with a list of desiderata, to see what could be improved. Surprisingly basically nothing could be improved. Bitcoin is in a tiny maxima spike in a vast design space

Everything inevitably has some dysfunction, human interaction and focus / work patterns are messy, the metric that counts is shared vision, continuous improvement, and shipping #bitcoin secure code and products/services. And have fun! In your zone shipping the cypherpunk future.

In the same way that Bitcoin has a dominance index in the cryptocurrency markets, the USD has one too. Right now, even while issuing more dollars, the dominance of the USD is rising, which will offset inflationary effects as global trade is weighted more toward the USD.
That’s what’s changed. Ten years ago, #Bitcoin was unknown to the people who were devastated by the Great Recession. Today, it’s an option.
And when governments around the world failed their people through nothing less than criminal monetary policy, people turned to #Bitcoin to protect their wealth.
The network has survived injuries that should’ve destroyed it. Mt. Gox, the scaling war, hacks and hijinks. #Bitcoin has matured, and adoption has increased despite those insults.
This time, we’re at the tail end of what I call the #Bitcoin Decade, and I believe Bitcoin is just beginning its ascendancy to dominance on the global stage.

The Great Recession of 2008 was just one in a long string of once-a-decade screw ups by the folks who run our financial system. Who doesn’t know this? Fleece the people, rinse, repeat. Tens years on, has #Bitcoin changed anything?
